repnme.cdata!:
Zimbabwe - Second Structural Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This Project Performance Assessment
            Report (PPAR) downgrades the Evaluation Summary outcome
            rating, from marginally satisfactory to highly
            unsatisfactory, institutional development from modest to
            negligible, sustainability from uncertain to highly
            unlikely, borrower performance from unsatisfactory to highly
            unsatisfactory, and, Bank performance from satisfactory to
            unsatisfactory. These ratings result from the fact that the
            objectives of restoring macroeconomic stability, improving
            public sector management, and shielding the poor from the
            transitional impact of adjustment, were not met. As for
            institutional development impacts, the project targeted
            reforms in the parastatal sector, where results were
            disappointing. Furthermore, the 1998-2000 period has been
            one of macroeconomic destabilization, with slippages in
            structural reforms, and forcible land acquisition, which has
            destroyed private sector confidence, and the core of
            efficient agriculture. Although the Bank correctly focused
            on liberalizing the economy, constraining parastatal losses,
            and on agricultural marketing reforms, it overestimated
            Government ownership of this project's reforms, and
            underestimated the risk to stabilization, and to private
            sector confidence. In addition, early analytic work to
            assist in public expenditure management was not planned, and
            the social impact of reforms not monitored. Regrettably, the
            Borrower, following 1997, reversed many of the reforms
            already implemented under the project. Lessons suggest a
            public expenditure review should have been undertaken early
            on; political dialogue and consensus built, rather than
            relying on commitments; and, tranche releases should be
            based on results, taking into account that poverty reduction
            is paramount in adjustment operations, particularly in
            low-income countries.

repnme.cdata!:
Zimbabwe - Second Structural Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Structural Adjustment Credit
            for Zimbabwe achieved a satisfactory overall outcome.
            Substantial progress was achieved in improving the business
            environment by reforming the exchange rate and trade regime,
            deregulating foreign and local investment, and liberalizing
            markets. However, the fiscal deficit was not brought down;
            deficits led to high nominal and real interest rates; the
            private sector was crowded out from domestic credit;
            increasing public debt service constrained allocations for
            the social sectors; and there was inadequate employment
            creation and poverty reduction. Program sustainability is
            rated as uncertain. Further progress is needed in
            expenditure rationalization, revenue enhancement, and asset
            and liability management. It will be necessary to foster a
            more equitable distribution of reform program benefits to
            maintain public support. Bank performance is rated as
            satisfactory, although noted issues include the operation
            design, economic strategy, and lack of explicit conditions
            on social sector spending. Borrower performance is rated as
            satisfactory in preparation and early implementation, but
            became uneven in later stages. Performance was poor in
            fiscal management; coordination of monetary, fiscal,
            exchange rate policies; and covenant compliance. The primary
            lesson learned is that, while the structural reform elements
            of the project were largely achieved and produced the
            expected results, such reforms cannot be fully effective in
            unstable macroeconomic conditions. Other lessons learned
            include: there is a need to link the adjustment operation
            more explicitly to the Bank's poverty reduction
            strategy; the ultimate success of the program will rely on
            the confidence of the private sector and civil society; and
            the systematic monitoring of the impact of reforms could
            have been more strongly supported as a condition for an
            adjustment operation.

18155693.majtheme: Rural development,Trade and integration,Financial and private sector development,Economic management

repnme.cdata!:
Zimbabwe - Second Structural Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Second Structural
            Adjustment Credit is to support the implementation of the
            second phase of Zimbabwe's structural adjustment
            program. Given good progress in the first phase of the
            program and taking into account the effects of the 1992
            drought, this support is appropriate and in line with the
            Bank's assistance strategy for Zimbabwe. The credit
            focuses on generating more rapid supply response, while
            continuing efforts to restore macroeconomic stability,
            improve public sector management and shield poor and
            vulnerable groups from harsh transitional effects arising
            from adjustment. To achieve the rapid increase in investment
            and exports which are vital to the sustainability and
            success of structural adjustment in Zimbabawe, the credit
            will support: (a) further trade policy reform to promote
            exports; (b) investment delicensing to facilitate an
            increase in private investment; and (c) agricultural
            marketing and price reform to broaden private sector
            involvement and competition.
